title: Nine targets tech giants with 'cost per completed view' ad model
text:
Nine is making an aggressive pitch to convince advertisers to move digital spending away from Facebook and Google to its model where clients across its digital and publishing portfolio will only be charged once an entire video ad has been viewed.

Nine chief sales officer Michael Stephenson and Nine director of Powered Liana Dubois. Louise Kennerley

"Over the course of the last five years, $700 million has been moved out of the television market into the social video market. In this year alone, close to a billion dollars will be spent on Facebook video and YouTube," said Nine's chief sales officer, Michael Stephenson.

"Call us a bit old fashioned but we believe that advertising you see is generally more effective. We shouldn’t accept that advertising that is seen for a second, or perhaps not at all, is more effective than advertising that is full screen where the sound is on that you see for the entire time."

Nine revealed the move to a 'cost per completed view' model at its annual upfronts as it unveiled its content and strategy for 2020 on Wednesday.

The change will be implemented across broadcast, video on-demand platform 9Now, and the digital destinations for The Australian Financial Review, The Sydney Morning Herald, The Age and Nine.com.au.
description: Nine is moving to a 'cost per completed view' model where advertisers won't pay for an ad unless it is played through, on screen, right to the end.
